questions.question: Cache level shared between cores but still on the CPU chip.
questions.explanation: L2 cache is larger than L1 and may be shared among cores.

questions.question: Largest cache level, often shared across all CPU cores.
questions.explanation: L3 cache is the slowest but largest on-chip cache level.

questions.question: RAM type that transfers data on both clock edges for double speed.
questions.explanation: DDR RAM transfers data twice per clock cycle for improved performance.

questions.question: Storage technique that distributes data across multiple drives for performance.
questions.explanation: RAID 0 stripes data across drives for faster read/write but no redundancy.

questions.question: Storage technique that mirrors data across drives for redundancy.
questions.explanation: RAID 1 duplicates data on multiple drives for fault tolerance.

questions.question: Memory addressing mode using both physical and virtual addresses.
questions.explanation: Paging divides memory into fixed-size pages for virtual memory management.

questions.question: The time taken for a storage device to locate and begin reading data.
questions.explanation: Seek time is the delay before data transfer begins, especially relevant for HDDs.

questions.question: Flash storage type that stores multiple bits per cell.
questions.explanation: MLC stores 2+ bits per cell, offering higher capacity but slower speeds than SLC.

questions.question: Flash storage type that stores three bits per cell.
questions.explanation: TLC provides more capacity at lower cost but with reduced endurance.

questions.question: Memory cache policy that replaces the least recently used data.
questions.explanation: LRU replacement policy evicts the data that hasn't been accessed for the longest time.
